10904Journal of Inorganic and Organometallic Polymers and MaterialsJ Inorg Organomet Polym1574-14431574-1451Springer USBostons10904-010-9347-8934710.1007/s10904-010-9347-8ArticleSynthesis, Crystal Structure and Luminescence Property of a New (6,3)-Connected Zn(II) Coordination PolymerWangAidong1QiuJianchao2GuoFeng3cZhangXiuling3LiuYongliang4grid.440766.7Department of ChemistryHuangshan University245041AnhuiPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.9227.e0000000119573309Qingdao Institute of BioEnergy and Bioprocess TechnologyChinese Academy of Sciences266101QingdaoPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.440709.e0000000098709448Department of ChemistryDezhou University253023ShandongPeople’s Republic of Chinagrid.440709.e0000000098709448Department of PhysicsDezhou University253023ShandongPeople’s Republic of China+86-534-8985835guofeng1510@yeah.net23320106201020229329711320102812200911320102332010© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20102010Abstract

The 2D coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n(H2dpa = 2,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of NaOH and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, FTIR spectra, element analysis and thermal analysis. The crystal structure determination reveals that the carboxylate groups of 2,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid are acting as bridging ligands and adopt two coordination modes; bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating. The network consists of a 2D (6,3)-connected architecture. At room temperature the solid-state luminescence spectrum of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n shows a blue emission at about 354 nm upon excitation at 333 nm.

The design and construction of Zn(II) coordination polymers has recently attracted considerable attention not only due to their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications for materials with photoluminescent and nonlinear optical properties [1–6]. It is well known that polyfunctional ligands such as dicarboxylic acid exhibit various network topologies [7–14]; therefore, the construction of coordination polymers using metal ions and anionic O-donor ligands is one of the hotspots in the field [15–18]. In addition, the prospect of introducing second organic ligands into a reaction system provides further impetus for research on metal–organic supramolecular frameworks. Among the second organic ligands, neutral N-donor ligands are often used [19, 20]. When an N-containing ligand is introduced into the reaction system, extended structural motifs based on these frameworks can be constructed. In this paper, we designed and synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, based on 2,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4′-dpa) and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) ligand.

ExperimentalGeneral Materials and Method

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a KBr pellet in the 400–4,000 cm−1 range. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA 851e analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under N2.

Synthesis

The hydrothermal reaction of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), H2dpa (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol), bpp (0.198 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting reaction products were colorless block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 68%, based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C27H22N2ZnO4: C, 64.36; H, 4.40; N, 5.56. Found: C, 65.08; H, 4.35; N, 5.58. IR: 1628s, 1562s, 1461s, 1305w, 1018w, 823m, 730m.

X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for synthesized compound were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [21]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the SHEXL 97 program [22]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometrical calculations, and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. In compound [Zn(dap)(bpp)]n, little crystallographic disorder was observed for the C40–C42 and C44–C47 of the bpp ligand. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analysis for the zinc coordination polymer are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond parameters are listed in Table 2.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure

The fundamental unit for the compound [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is show in Fig. 1. There are two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions. Zn(1) is five-coordinate with four oxygen atoms from four dpa ligands [Zn(1)–O(3) = 2.039(2) Å, Zn(1)–O(4) = 2.030(2) Å, Zn(1)–O(5) = 2.056(2) Å and Zn(1)–O(6) = 2.046(2) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Zn(1)–N(1) = 2.025(2) Å] from a bpp ligand to give square-pyramidal geometries (Fig. 1a). It is interesting to note that four carboxylate groups bridge the dinuclear Zn(II) center in a syn–syn coordination mode, which gives rise to paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBU). The Zn⋯Zn separation within the SBU is 2.975 Å. Zn(2) is six-coordinate with four oxygen atoms [Zn(2)–O(1) = 2.141(2) Å, Zn(2)–O(2) = 2.189(2) Å, Zn(2)–O(7) = 2.095(2) Å and Zn(2)–O(8) = 2.274(2) Å] from two dpa ligands and two nitrogen atoms [Zn(2)–N(2) = 2.143(3) Å and Zn(2)–N(3) = 2.099(3) Å] from two bpp ligands to give octahedral geometries (Fig. 1b). The distances are within that range of reported complexes [23, 24]. The carboxylate groups are twisted with respect to the correspondingly linked phenyl rings with dihedral angles of 0.73° and 33.52°; the two phenyl rings about the central bond have a twist with a dihedral angle of 58.85°. There are two conformations for the bpp ligands in [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n: TT and TG. The ligands of the TT conformation act as a bidentate μ2-ligand and the ligands of TG conformation act as a monodentate μ1-ligand [25–27].

Better insight into the frameworks can be accessed by the topology method: based on considerations of the their connectivity and the SBU. Zn(2) can be viewed as six- and three-connected nodes. The combination of nodes suggests (6,3)-connected frameworks for the compound with (43)2(46·66·83)—in topological notation (Fig. 2).

TGA

To investigate the thermal stability of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, TGA was performed (Fig. 3). [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is stable to 280 °C. Upon further heating, decomposition begins and the total weight loss at 600 °C is 84.37%, which corresponds to complete removal of the organic component. The final residue is ZnO (observed 15.63%, calcd. 16.15%).

Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n and the H2dpa ligand at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 4. [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n exhibits an intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 354 nm on excitation at 333 nm. Free H2dpa and bpp display intense fluorescent properties in the solid state at room temperature with emission maxima at 354 and 523 nm [28], respectively.

The Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d10 configuration. Thus, the fluorescent emission of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is neither a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Thus, we have assigned the band to an intra-ligand (π–π*) fluorescent emission of dpa [29, 30]. The enhancement of the intensity in the metal complex may be attributed to the increased rigidity of the ligand upon metal coordination, which effectively reduces energy loss [31, 32].

Conclusions

We successfully synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, with a 2-D layer structure. The structural characterization shows that the carboxylate group acts in a bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating mode. Moreover, the solid state luminescent spectrum demonstrates that [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is a good candidate as a photoactive material.

Supplementary Data

elements.content: The 2D coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n(H2dpa = 2,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of NaOH and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, FTIR spectra, element analysis and thermal analysis. The crystal structure determination reveals that the carboxylate groups of 2,4′-biphenyldicarboxylic acid are acting as bridging ligands and adopt two coordination modes; bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating. The network consists of a 2D (6,3)-connected architecture. At room temperature the solid-state luminescence spectrum of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n shows a blue emission at about 354 nm upon excitation at 333 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The 2D coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n(H2dpa = 2,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid, bpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) was prepared by hydrothermal synthesis in the presence of NaOH and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, FTIR spectra, element analysis and thermal analysis. The crystal structure determination reveals that the carboxylate groups of 2,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid are acting as bridging ligands and adopt two coordination modes; bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating. The network consists of a 2D (6,3)-connected architecture. At room temperature the solid-state luminescence spectrum of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n shows a blue emission at about 354 nm upon excitation at 333 nm.

elements.content: The design and construction of Zn(II) coordination polymers has recently attracted considerable attention not only due to their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications for materials with photoluminescent and nonlinear optical properties [1–6]. It is well known that polyfunctional ligands such as dicarboxylic acid exhibit various network topologies [7–14]; therefore, the construction of coordination polymers using metal ions and anionic O-donor ligands is one of the hotspots in the field [15–18]. In addition, the prospect of introducing second organic ligands into a reaction system provides further impetus for research on metal–organic supramolecular frameworks. Among the second organic ligands, neutral N-donor ligands are often used [19, 20]. When an N-containing ligand is introduced into the reaction system, extended structural motifs based on these frameworks can be constructed. In this paper, we designed and synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, based on 2,4′-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4′-dpa) and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of Zn(II) coordination polymers has recently attracted considerable attention not only due to their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications for materials with photoluminescent and nonlinear optical properties [1-6]. It is well known that polyfunctional ligands such as dicarboxylic acid exhibit various network topologies [7-14]; therefore, the construction of coordination polymers using metal ions and anionic O-donor ligands is one of the hotspots in the field [15-18]. In addition, the prospect of introducing second organic ligands into a reaction system provides further impetus for research on metal-organic supramolecular frameworks. Among the second organic ligands, neutral N-donor ligands are often used [19, 20]. When an N-containing ligand is introduced into the reaction system, extended structural motifs based on these frameworks can be constructed. In this paper, we designed and synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, based on 2,4'-biphenyl-dicarboxylic acid (2,4'-dpa) and 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp) ligand.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a KBr pellet in the 400–4,000 cm−1 range. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA 851e analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under N2.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

General Materials and Method

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Elemental analysis was carried out on a Carlo Erba 1106 full-automatic trace organic elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra were recorded with a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer as a KBr pellet in the 400-4,000 cm-1 range. Solid-state fluorescence spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer equipped with a xenon lamp and a quartz carrier. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out with a Mettler Toledo TGA 851e analyzer at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under N2.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of Zn(OAc)2·2H2O (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), H2dpa (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol), bpp (0.198 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting reaction products were colorless block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 68%, based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C27H22N2ZnO4: C, 64.36; H, 4.40; N, 5.56. Found: C, 65.08; H, 4.35; N, 5.58. IR: 1628s, 1562s, 1461s, 1305w, 1018w, 823m, 730m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

The hydrothermal reaction of Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.108 g, 0.5 mmol), H2dpa (0.121 g, 0.5 mmol), bpp (0.198 g, 1 mmol), NaOH (0.04 g, 1 mmol) and distilled water (18 mL) was heated to 160 °C for 96 h in a 25 mL stainless steel reactor with a Teflon liner, followed by slow cooling to room temperature. The resulting reaction products were colorless block crystals that were washed with alcohol to give pure samples (Yield: 68%, based on Zn). Elemental Anal. Calcd. (%) for C27H22N2ZnO4: C, 64.36; H, 4.40; N, 5.56. Found: C, 65.08; H, 4.35; N, 5.58. IR: 1628s, 1562s, 1461s, 1305w, 1018w, 823m, 730m.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for synthesized compound were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [21]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the SHEXL 97 program [22]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometrical calculations, and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. In compound [Zn(dap)(bpp)]n, little crystallographic disorder was observed for the C40–C42 and C44–C47 of the bpp ligand. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analysis for the zinc coordination polymer are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond parameters are listed in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Diffraction intensities for synthesized compound were collected on a Bruker Smart 1000 CCD area-detector diffractometer with a Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using the ω-scan mode. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS programs [21]. All the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 using the SHEXL 97 program [22]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms were located by geometrical calculations, and their positions and thermal parameters were fixed during the structural refinement. In compound [Zn(dap)(bpp)]n, little crystallographic disorder was observed for the C40-C42 and C44-C47 of the bpp ligand. The crystallographic data and experimental details of structural analysis for the zinc coordination polymer are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond parameters are listed in Table 2.

The fundamental unit for the compound [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is show in Fig. 1. There are two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions. Zn(1) is five-coordinate with four oxygen atoms from four dpa ligands [Zn(1)–O(3) = 2.039(2) Å, Zn(1)–O(4) = 2.030(2) Å, Zn(1)–O(5) = 2.056(2) Å and Zn(1)–O(6) = 2.046(2) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Zn(1)–N(1) = 2.025(2) Å] from a bpp ligand to give square-pyramidal geometries (Fig. 1a). It is interesting to note that four carboxylate groups bridge the dinuclear Zn(II) center in a syn–syn coordination mode, which gives rise to paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBU). The Zn⋯Zn separation within the SBU is 2.975 Å. Zn(2) is six-coordinate with four oxygen atoms [Zn(2)–O(1) = 2.141(2) Å, Zn(2)–O(2) = 2.189(2) Å, Zn(2)–O(7) = 2.095(2) Å and Zn(2)–O(8) = 2.274(2) Å] from two dpa ligands and two nitrogen atoms [Zn(2)–N(2) = 2.143(3) Å and Zn(2)–N(3) = 2.099(3) Å] from two bpp ligands to give octahedral geometries (Fig. 1b). The distances are within that range of reported complexes [23, 24]. The carboxylate groups are twisted with respect to the correspondingly linked phenyl rings with dihedral angles of 0.73° and 33.52°; the two phenyl rings about the central bond have a twist with a dihedral angle of 58.85°. There are two conformations for the bpp ligands in [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n: TT and TG. The ligands of the TT conformation act as a bidentate μ2-ligand and the ligands of TG conformation act as a monodentate μ1-ligand [25–27].
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The fundamental unit for the compound [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is show in Fig. 1. There are two crystallographically independent Zn(II) ions. Zn(1) is five-coordinate with four oxygen atoms from four dpa ligands [Zn(1)-O(3) = 2.039(2) Å, Zn(1)-O(4) = 2.030(2) Å, Zn(1)-O(5) = 2.056(2) Å and Zn(1)-O(6) = 2.046(2) Å] and one nitrogen atom [Zn(1)-N(1) = 2.025(2) Å] from a bpp ligand to give square-pyramidal geometries (Fig. 1a). It is interesting to note that four carboxylate groups bridge the dinuclear Zn(II) center in a syn-syn coordination mode, which gives rise to paddle-wheel secondary building units (SBU). The Zn⋯Zn separation within the SBU is 2.975 Å. Zn(2) is six-coordinate with four oxygen atoms [Zn(2)-O(1) = 2.141(2) Å, Zn(2)-O(2) = 2.189(2) Å, Zn(2)-O(7) = 2.095(2) Å and Zn(2)-O(8) = 2.274(2) Å] from two dpa ligands and two nitrogen atoms [Zn(2)-N(2) = 2.143(3) Å and Zn(2)-N(3) = 2.099(3) Å] from two bpp ligands to give octahedral geometries (Fig. 1b). The distances are within that range of reported complexes [23, 24]. The carboxylate groups are twisted with respect to the correspondingly linked phenyl rings with dihedral angles of 0.73° and 33.52°; the two phenyl rings about the central bond have a twist with a dihedral angle of 58.85°. There are two conformations for the bpp ligands in [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n: TT and TG. The ligands of the TT conformation act as a bidentate μ2-ligand and the ligands of TG conformation act as a monodentate μ1-ligand [25-27].

elements.content: To investigate the thermal stability of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, TGA was performed (Fig. 3). [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is stable to 280 °C. Upon further heating, decomposition begins and the total weight loss at 600 °C is 84.37%, which corresponds to complete removal of the organic component. The final residue is ZnO (observed 15.63%, calcd. 16.15%).
elements.clean_text:
TGA

To investigate the thermal stability of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, TGA was performed (Fig. 3). [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is stable to 280 °C. Upon further heating, decomposition begins and the total weight loss at 600 °C is 84.37%, which corresponds to complete removal of the organic component. The final residue is ZnO (observed 15.63%, calcd. 16.15%).

elements.content: TGA curve of the compound [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n

The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n and the H2dpa ligand at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 4. [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n exhibits an intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 354 nm on excitation at 333 nm. Free H2dpa and bpp display intense fluorescent properties in the solid state at room temperature with emission maxima at 354 and 523 nm [28], respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n and the H2dpa ligand at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 4. [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n exhibits an intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 354 nm on excitation at 333 nm. Free H2dpa and bpp display intense fluorescent properties in the solid state at room temperature with emission maxima at 354 and 523 nm [28], respectively.

elements.content: The Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d10 configuration. Thus, the fluorescent emission of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is neither a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Thus, we have assigned the band to an intra-ligand (π–π*) fluorescent emission of dpa [29, 30]. The enhancement of the intensity in the metal complex may be attributed to the increased rigidity of the ligand upon metal coordination, which effectively reduces energy loss [31, 32].
elements.clean_text: The Zn(II) ion is difficult to oxidize or reduce due to its d10 configuration. Thus, the fluorescent emission of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is neither a metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor a ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). Thus, we have assigned the band to an intra-ligand (π-π*) fluorescent emission of dpa [29, 30]. The enhancement of the intensity in the metal complex may be attributed to the increased rigidity of the ligand upon metal coordination, which effectively reduces energy loss [31, 32].

elements.content: We successfully synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, with a 2-D layer structure. The structural characterization shows that the carboxylate group acts in a bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating mode. Moreover, the solid state luminescent spectrum demonstrates that [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is a good candidate as a photoactive material.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We successfully synthesized a new coordination polymer, [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, with a 2-D layer structure. The structural characterization shows that the carboxylate group acts in a bis-monodentate and bidentate chelating mode. Moreover, the solid state luminescent spectrum demonstrates that [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is a good candidate as a photoactive material.

The network consists of a 2D (6,3)-connected architecture. At room temperature the solid-state luminescence spectrum of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n shows a blue emission at about 354 nm upon excitation at 333 nm.

TGA

To investigate the thermal stability of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n, TGA was performed (Fig. 3). [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n is stable to 280 °C. Upon further heating, decomposition begins and the total weight loss at 600 °C is 84.37%, which corresponds to complete removal of the organic component. The final residue is ZnO (observed 15.63%, calcd. 16.15%).

Photoluminescent Properties

The solid-state photoluminescent spectra of [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n and the H2dpa ligand at room temperature are depicted in Fig. 4. [Zn(dpa)(bpp)]n exhibits an intense blue photoluminescence with an emission maximum at ca. 354 nm on excitation at 333 nm. Free H2dpa and bpp display intense fluorescent properties in the solid state at room temperature with emission maxima at 354 and 523 nm [28], respectively.
